posts.cooked:
Wow, this is huge!

With iMessage Contact Key Verification, users can verify they are communicating only with whom they intend. With Security Keys for Apple ID, users have the choice to require a physical security key to sign in to their Apple ID account. And with Advanced Data Protection for iCloud, which uses end-to-end encryption to provide Apple’s highest level of cloud data security, users have the choice to further protect important iCloud data, including iCloud Backup, Photos, Notes, and more.

iMessage Contact Key Verification will be available globally in 2023.
Security Keys for Apple ID will be available globally in early 2023.
Advanced Data Protection for iCloud is available in the US today for members of the Apple Beta Software Program, and will be available to US users by the end of the year. The feature will start rolling out to the rest of the world in early 2023.

Apple-advanced-security-iMessage-Contact-Key-Verification1306×1828 229 KB

Apple-advanced-security-Security-Keys_inline.jpg.large_2x1306×1828 107 KB

Apple-advanced-security-Advanced-Data-Protection_inline.jpg.large_2x1306×1828 195 KB

Because of the need to interoperate with the global email, contacts, and calendar systems, iCloud Mail, Contacts, and Calendar aren’t end-to-end encrypted.

Source:

  • Apple advances user security with powerful new data protections - Apple
  • Advanced Data Protection for iCloud - Apple Support
Mastodon – 7 Dec 22

Meredith Whittaker (@Mer__edith@mastodon.world)

Big credit to the privacy advocates who pushed back on troubling surveillance practices and made this happen! This kind of win often gets framed as a company's choice, when smart and difficult campaigning did so much of the work behind the...

https://mastodon.lol/@evacide/109473876383994259

posts.cooked: I’m literally crying right now. It this true or I’m just dreaming?

Very good news! I’d still probably only backup my iPhone locally but good to know that I have the option of using iCloud Backup, iCloud Photos and more without worrying about Apple having access (though it is proprietary). It is unfortunate that the end-to-end encrypted iCloud Backups and that are opt-in and not the default but better than not offering it at all.

Will this allow you to back-up Signal messages as well, E2EE in Apple’s iCloud backup ?

this is probably a stupid question … but I have no idea how Signal-iOS and iOS works

anon61006462:

Will this allow you to back-up Signal messages as well, E2EE in Apple’s iCloud backup ?

this is probably a stupid question … but I have no idea how Signal-iOS and iOS works

That’s definitely not a stupid question

Simplest explanation would be that iOS backs up certain default directories in which you (= app) can store data. Like Documents, or Library (/var/mobile/Containers/Data/Application/[UUID]/Library/).

Signal stores their (our?) database outside of such “predefined” directories - in /var/mobile/Containers/Shared/AppGroup/[UUID]/grdb/signal.sqlite

More information about Apple’s file system: File System Basics

Update: some more detailed information about Signal’s inner workings

There’s a way to explicitly exclude stuff from being backed up using NSURLIsExcludedFromBackupKey (as described in Apple’s specification above)

github.com

signalapp/Signal-iOS/blob/35bc42d159f0652900aa8bf3892415a533f20b00/SignalServiceKit/src/Util/OWSFileSystem.m#L47-L90

    3.

    4.

  5.     }
    6. 
          
  6.     if (![NSFileManager.defaultManager fileExistsAtPath:path]) {
    7.

    14.

    15.

    16.

    17.

And it seems that this manual exclusion is needed in some cases :

signalapp/Signal-iOS/blob/ccb1e46ac1b9d2c527d9e691f9862faef33146df/SignalMessaging/environment/AppSetup.m#L50-L59

    3.

    4.

    5.

    6.

    7.

    8.

    9.

Thank you ! ­­­­­­­ ­

This does not mean much. You cannot be sure whether they will silently add a key for the FBI/NSA/whatever or not.

There’s no source code available and you can’t even look at the file system of iOS devices easily.

There’s no source code available and you can’t even look at the file system of iOS devices easily.

Not having the source code doesn’t mean the implementation can’t be audited, it’s a common misconception. Closed source software is routinely audited to find bugs and vulnerabilities. iOS devices in particular are reverse engineered all the time since their inception.

QuickBanana:

Not having the source code doesn’t mean the implementation can’t be audited, it’s a common misconception.

An audit does not get you anything as close to what open source does. They should publish the source code for at least this important bit that requires trust.

If many people look at the code that’s far better than few people doing code audits, because humans can miss things.

In the binaries is a lot of space, anywhere in the system, to have something that allows adding another key, for the FBI/NSA/any other three letter agency.
If you assume the implementation has a backdoor then auditing the source code given by them would be pointless, you necessarily need to verify the on device binaries.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
QuickBanana:

Not having the source code doesn’t mean the implementation can’t be audited, it’s a common misconception. Closed source software is routinely audited to find bugs and vulnerabilities. iOS devices in particular are reverse engineered all the time since their inception.

Yet it’s concerning that Apple can target specific devices with a specific build with little to no issue compared to even Android manufacturers, which have some form of insider attack protection via the secure element.

GrapheneOS

GrapheneOS Frequently Asked Questions

Answers to frequently asked questions about GrapheneOS.

There’s a history of Apple contacting agencies offering to help them unlock devices (in spite news articles erroneously saying they refuse). Doesn’t seem to happen much now, but I doubt they’ve removed that ability.

That being said I’m not up to date on what Apple has been doing in particular in this area, so feel free to correct me.

Whatnoww:

insider attack protection

If this is what you are referring to, it doesn’t look like it prevents Google from targeting a specific device with a specific build, but rather prevent firmware upgrades without entering the phone PIN, a feature missing on iOS.

Whatnoww:

compared to even Android manufacturers

Which, other than Google Pixel devices?

Whatnoww:

There’s a history of Apple contacting agencies offering to help them unlock devices (in spite news articles erroneously saying they refuse). Doesn’t seem to happen much now, but I doubt they’ve removed that ability.

According to Apple legal docs, they can help unlocking devices with iOS <= 7, where the encryption is not tied to the passcode.

link_counts.title: Android Developers Blog: Insider Attack Resistance

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Yes, I meant updating firmware, sorry for being unclear. That’s always going to be a point of contention for me. Insider attack protection is also strongly recommended by Android and does seem to be around since Android 9. Can’t comment on the implementation but seems to be an Android feature, rather than a Pixel feature.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Two important question to ask now:

  1. What method/protocol will they be using for such an encryption?
  2. Regarding Eva: "Apple has finally killed its ill-conceived plan t…" - Mastodon.lol, are they still planning on scanning photos before uploading, like it has been recently demonstrated they do? Because the existing tools undermine the iCloud security quite a lot.

link_counts.title: Eva: "Apple has finally killed its ill-conceived plan t…" - Mastodon.lol

posts.cooked:
I’m gonna get cancelled for defending Apple yet again, but here we go…

Talya (she/her):

are they still planning on scanning photos before uploading

[T]he company told WIRED in a statement. “We have further decided to not move forward with our previously proposed CSAM detection tool for iCloud Photos. Children can be protected without companies combing through personal data, and we will continue working with governments, child advocates, and other companies to help protect young people, preserve their right to privacy, and make the internet a safer place for children and for us all.”

Talya (she/her):

scanning photos […] like it has been recently demonstrated they do

I guess you’re referring to this recent tempest in a teapot:

DEF CON Social – 22 Jan 23

Mysk🇨🇦🇩🇪 (@mysk@defcon.social)

🚨New 🧵: (1/6) No, macOS doesn't send info about your local photos to #Apple We analyzed mediaanalysisd after an extraordinary claim by Jeffrey Paul that it scans local photos and secretly sends the results to an Apple...

DEF CON Social – 22 Jan 23

Mysk🇨🇦🇩🇪 (@mysk@defcon.social)

Attached: 1 image (4/6) Ok, so why does mediaanalysisd send data to Apple? We analyzed the network traffic sent and received by mediaanalysisd. Well, the call is literally empty. We decrypted it. No headers, no IDs, nothing. Just a simple GET...

DEF CON Social – 22 Jan 23

Mysk🇨🇦🇩🇪 (@mysk@defcon.social)

(6/6) Conclusion: mediaanalysisd doesn't send any data to Apple about your local photos. The network call is clearly a bug. Or Apple has disabled the feature remotely, which is very unlikely. We tested on macOS 13.1 with and without iCloud. Thanks...

(Fixed in macOS 13.2)

Talya (she/her):

What method/protocol will they be using for such an encryption?

Conceptually, Advanced Data Protection is simple: All CloudKit Service keys that were generated on device and later uploaded to the available-after-authentication iCloud Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) in Apple data centers are deleted from those HSMs and instead kept entirely within the account’s iCloud Keychain protection domain. They are handled like the existing end-to-end encrypted service keys, which means Apple can no longer read or access these keys.

1480×746 157 KB

help.apple.com

apple-platform-security-guide.pdf

2.32 MB

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: well, that’s all my questions answered

Not available anymore for new customers in UK, existing customers will be told to disable encryption or lose iCloud data.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2025/02/21/apple-yanks-encrypted-storage-uk-instead-allowing-backdoor-access/
Which really sucks, thanks to the governments.
Get ready for other governments demanding the same after this huge precedent.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
This is circumstantial evidence that Apple does not backdoor ADP, which is nice, since I do use it on iOS devices. They also don’t seem to have a mechanism to re-encrypt and re-upload automatically, hence forcing you to loose data which is a good thing for these sort of encrypted services.

I support Apple in the sense that they seem to implement security and privacy reasonably (iMessages follows a lot of Signal’s practices). It’s a shame they’re the only large option available, and for smartphones you need to either use Apple’s integrated services or use GrapheneOS. Too little options.
